terms.term: What are the two types of conformity and define
terms.definition:
Internalisation: privately changing personal views permanently ( deep type of conformity where we take on the majority view because we genuinely believe it / accept it as correct) 

Compliance: Temporary public acting in with wishes / actions of others whilst privately maintaining our own views. ( surface level conformity to gain approval from others or avoid their disapproval )

Information ta social influence is the agreeing of the opinion of the majority because we believe it is correct and we want to be right also. Closely linked to internalisation as a deeper level of influence
Normative social influence is an explanation of conformity where we agree with the majority because we want to be liked and fit in. Clearly linked to compliance as it is surface level conformity.
A change in a person’s behaviour/thoughts/opinions as a result of a real/imagined pressure from a person or group of people,.
When a larger group of people changes the behaviours/beliefs/attitudes of a smaller group (linked to compliance)
When a smaller group of people changes the behaviours/beliefs/attitudes of a larger group (linked to internalisation.

terms.term: 16 marker basic question ao1 social influence
terms.definition: AO1: Conformity, as outlined by the 2-process theory of Gerrard and Deutsch, has two theorised explanations; Informational social influence(ISI): the theory that behaviour is changed in order to conform to the majority’s beliefs/actions due to the desire to be right / the fear to be wrong, and normative social influence(NSI): the theory that behaviour is changed to conform to the majority’s beliefs/actions due to the desire to fit-in and be liked. ISI is closely linked to internalisation (a deep, permanent type of conformity) as it involves wanting to be right, so you start believing the actions are correct and as a result you change your personal and public opinions to that of the majority. An example of ISI could be going on an LGBTQ+ march with a group of your friends who support the movement and subsequently changing your private views permanently in favour of the LGBTQ+ community. NSI is closely linked to compliance, a surface-level, temporary type of conformity) as it involves wanting to fit in, so differing personal views are maintained in private but altered to fit the majority in public. An example of NSI is wearing a specific brand of clothing in public eg. Hollister clothes, despite not liking the style because everyone else is wearing it and you want to fit in.

terms.term: EVAL ao3 16m basic social influence : schultz +nsi
terms.definition: One positive feature is the research evidence for the 2-process theory of conformity under Schultz which supported the idea of normative social influence. Schultz found that hotel guests exposed to the normative message that 75% of guests reused their towels each day (rather than requiring fresh towels) reduced their own towel use by 25%. This research suggests that the other guests thought that the majority of people were reusing their towels and therefore didn’t want to be different/ wanted to fit in, so changed their behaviour to reuse their own towels in order to fit in. Consequently, this evidence supports the idea of normative social influence which can explain conformity so therefore it can be said to be an accurate theory.

terms.term: EVAL ao3 16m basic social influence : asch +isi
terms.definition: One negative feature is the research evidence which can be said to contradict the informational social influence aspect of the 2-process theory. For example Asch found that students were less conformist (28% than other participants (37%)in his pencil line study. Perrin and Spencer also found that science students showed very little conformity in their respective studies. This evidence shows how informational social influence may not be an explanation of conformity for everyone as people who are more confident in their knowledge (eg. Science students)/ are not necessarily in an ambiguous situation so are less likely to conform.) Overall perhaps this evidence suggests that not everyone is influenced by ISI in the same manner, and different groups of people may be more or less likely to conform as a result of informational social influence. Consequently, this study doesn’t support that the 2-process theory can wholly explain conformity so it can be said to be over-simplified.

terms.term: EVAL ao3 16m basic social influence : jennesse + 2-pt
terms.definition: Another positive feature is Jennesse’s study where participants were asked to estimate the number of beans in a jar and the group always tended to converge to a group norm. This evidence shows how the 2-process theory influences conformity as participants relayed that they altered their original answer to be similar to the rest of the group either to be liked/ to fit in or to be correct. This shows how in ambiguous situations people tend to fear being different or fear being wrong so find comfort or safety in following the majority. Consequently this evidence supports the idea of the 2-process theory which can explain conformity as it can be said to plausible and accurate.

-)Lacks temporal validity: we can question the relation of what results were then and if they can be generalised to nowadays as would likely be different now given that in the 1950s conformity was promoted and more prevalent. Eg. Traditional - everyone did similar things, married at 20, 2.4 kids each and standing out was an issue. Therefore less valid due to difference in time frame study conducted as nowadays being a disruptor is celebrated and people lead more varied and modern lifestyles, so asch’s results may not be consistent across time and may only be relevant to the 1950s.
-/+)can’t be validly generalised: Perrin and spencer replicated aschs study with engineering students in UK in 1980 and found they were less conformist (only 1 conformed to of 360) because they had more confidence in their own abilities when measuring lines. This suggests that factors affecting conformity impact people differently which can depend on their course/skills. Therefore this contradicted aschs experiment as results were much lower, however it could support aschs hypothesis which considers the relation of task difficulty when measuring conformity.
-/+)artificial research which lacks eternal validity: lab experiment means pts weren’t in natural environment combined with use of demand characteristics (obviousness of confederates incorrect answers) leads to increased likelihood of abnormal behaviour - result less valid. Lacks mundane realism as task was not reflective of tasks performed in every day life, therefore cannot be used as completely comprehensive evidence for conformity in real life. However, use of lab meant highly controlled, so internal validity was high resulting in a clear cause and effect relationship concerning the IV and DV in the study.  
-/+) ethics: to evaluate study, cost benefit analysis. Whilst pts were deceived right from the beginning as asch didn’t tell them true aim of study, this would’ve likely caused them to act based upon how they believe they should act and not how they subconsciously would in the real world (abnormal behaviour) so more benefit as otherwise study would’ve been invalid. Bc true aim wasn’t revealed, no informed consent so this was violated but was outweighed by abnormal behaviour threat. No psychological harm and distress other than embarrassment and uncomfortable potentially. Privacy and confidentiality was for the most part maintained. Overall, it was a valuable piece of research which helps us to display human tendencies and further understand it, which could lead to factors affecting conformity being used to our advantage when trying to improve society as a whole, eg. End racism.

terms.term: What are some theorised origins of the authoritarian personality
terms.definition: Adorno et al believed AP forms in childhood mostly as a result of harsh parenting ricked discipline, absolute loyalty impossibly high standards and severe criticism of perceived failings, conditional love. Adorno argued that these childhood experience create resentment and hostility in a child however the child cannot express feelings directly because they fear punishment so fizz are displaced onto others who they perceive to be weaker through scapegoating. This explains why central feature of the AP is hatred towards people considered socially inferior or we belong to different social groups ( psychodynamic explanation.)

+) one strength is evidence from Milgrim study supporting the AP. Milgrim alongside elms interviewed a small sample who had participated in the original obedience studies and being fully obedient they completed the F scale as part of the interview. These 20 participants scored significantly higher on the overall S scale and a comparison group of 20 disobedient participants the two groups were clearly quite different in terms of authoritarianism. This finding supports Adornos view that obedient people show similar characteristics to people who have an AP.
Counterpoint ) however when the researchers analyse their individual sub skills of the F scale they found obedient participants had a number of characteristics that were unusual for authoritarians e.g. they did not glorify their fathers generally or experience unusually high levels of punishment in childhood or did not have particularly hostile attitudes towards their mothers. This means that the link between obedience and authoritarianism is complex so AP is unlikely to be a useful predictor of obedience.
-) one limitation is the AP cannot explain obedient behaviour in the majority of a countries population e.g. in pre-war Germany millions of people display obedient and antisemitic behaviour. This was regardless of differing personalities so it’s impossible. They all possess an AP and alternative views that the majority of people identified with the antisemitic Nazi state and Scape goat the outgroup Jewish people a social identity theory approach. Therefore, a Dorno theory is limited because an alternative explanation is much more realistic.
-) another limitation is the F scale only captures one kind of authoritarianism so it is an incomplete explanation. This is because it measures the tendency towards extreme right wing politics however.Mallinas suggest the F scale actually measures two elements: submission and traditionalism. Because only submission is strong and left-wing authoritarians while both are strong and right wing authoritarian submission is the key element in authoritarian behaviour and therefore Adornos theory cannot explain all historical incidents of destructive obedience.
Education may determine authoritarianism and obedience as research generally find the less educated or consistently more authoritarian e.g. Milgrim found participants with lower levels of education tended to be more obedient. This suggests that instead of authoritarianism causing obedience lack of education could be responsible for both authoritarianism and obedience. 
Research is correlational: Adorno found many significant correlation between authoritarianism and prejudice however no matter how strongly correlated the variables it doesn’t show that one variable cause the effect on the other so unidentified distinct cause-and-effect relationship

terms.term: What 3 main processes did moscovici draw attention to through his research?
terms.definition:
Consistency: minority must be consistent in their views as this increases interest from others. There are two types of consistency such as synchronic (says the same thing) and diachronic (say the same thing over time). Consistency starts making people rethink their own views (“if they all believe that maybe they’ve got a point”)
Commitment: sometimes minorities engage in extreme activities which often involve personal sacrifice to draw attention to their views and demonstrate greater commitment and compel ppl to think ‘she must really believe in that cause maybe I should consider it’. (Augmentation principle)
Flexibility: consistency can be off putting as people seem rigid,dogmatic and unbending. This can cause people to refuse to consider views which dont consider their opinions. The minority must be able to accept reasonable counter-arguments.

Minority influence is most effective if the minority keeps the same beliefs both overtime and between all the individuals that formed the minority consistency is effective because it draws attention to the minority view

Minority influence is more powerful if the minority demonstrates dedication to their position for example by making personal sacrifices this is effective because it shows the minority is not acting out of self interest

Relentless consistency could be counter-productive if it is seen by the majority as unbending and unreasonable therefore minority influence is more effective if minority also show flexibility by accepting the possibility of compromise
